div.p: Experiment solitary touching prolongation of life. 292. It conduceth unto long life, and to the more placid motion of the spirits which thereby do less prey and consume the juice of the body, either that mens actions be free and voluntary, that nothing be done invita Minerva, but secundum genium; or on the other side that the actions of men be full of regulation and commands within themselves: for then the victory and performing of the command giveth a good disposition to the spirits; especially if there be a proceeding from degree to degree; for then the sense of the victory is the greater. An example of the former of these is in a country life: and of the latter in monks and philosophers, and such as do continually enjoy themselves.
